questions.text: Identify the incorrect statement among the following:

options.label: A
options.text: Merkel cells & Melanocytes are present in Stratum Basale

options.label: B
options.text: Separation of keratinocytes is called as Acantholysis

options.label: C
options.text: Thickening of Stratum spinosum is called as Acanthosis

options.label: D
options.text: Skin turnover time in Psoriasis is 8 Weeks

questions.correct_answer: D. Skin turnover time in Psoriasis is 8 Weeks
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Skin turnover time in Psoriasis is 8 Weeks

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The educational objective is to recognize that the skin turnover time in psoriasis is significantly accelerated compared to normal skin turnover. Understanding the pathophysiology of skin changes in psoriasis is essential for diagnosing and managing the condition.

questions.text: A 47-year-old patient underwent surgery for a skin lesion on the abdomen. The incision was made perpendicular to the natural lines of skin tension, resulting in the wound edges gaping and healing poorly. What anatomical concept explains this phenomenon?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Langer's lines

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Langer's lines, or tension lines, are crucial for surgical planning as incisions made parallel to these lines result in better wound healing and less scarring.

questions.text: A 52-year-old patient presents to the dermatology clinic with complaints of sagging skin and wrinkles. They are seeking advice on maintaining youthful skin. The dermatologist explains that the skin's dermis primarily contains a specific fiber type responsible for its strength and resilience. What is the predominant fiber type in the skin's dermis that contributes to its tensile strength?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Collagen

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Collagen is the primary structural protein in the skin's dermis, providing strength and resilience, which is essential for maintaining youthful, firm skin.

questions.text: A farmer comes to skin OPD with the painful, swollen foot which has discharging sinuses and dark grains coming out of sinuses. Gram stain was negative. Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Eumycetoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Eumycetoma is a chronic fungal infection that presents with discharging sinuses and dark grains, typically in agricultural workers or those with repeated trauma to the feet. The negative Gram stain and the presence of dark grains point towards a fungal etiology over a bacterial one.

questions.text: A 55-year-old farmer presents with multiple verrucous lesions on his foot, as shown in the image, which developed after a thorn prick several months ago. Microscopy of a biopsy shows sclerotic bodies (as seen in the right image). What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Chromoblastomycosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Chromoblastomycosis is a chronic fungal infection characterized by verrucous skin lesions and the presence of sclerotic bodies (Medlar bodies) on histopathology.
  • ➤ Chromoblastomycosis
  • ➤ sclerotic bodies (Medlar bodies)

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient had history of thorn prick while working in a rose garden and later observed linear spread proximally till his shoulder . Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause for this clinical feature?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Lymphangitis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Lymphangitis is characterized by red streaking on the skin, which represents inflammation of the lymphatic channels, usually occurring secondary to an infectious process spreading from a distal site of injury, such as a thorn prick.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child presents with lesion on occipital region of head as shown in the image below. On examination boggy swelling was noted over scalp. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Tinea capitis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Identify tinea capitis as the most likely diagnosis in a patient presenting with a lesion on the occipital region of the head accompanied by a boggy swelling, indicative of a kerion, a classic presentation of a fungal scalp infection.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is treated with permethrin?
questions.explanation: Ans. A) Scabies

questions.text: A 22-year-old male patient from Jaipur presents with an erythematous lesion on the cheek with central crusting. Considering the geographic location and clinical presentation, What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Ans.

questions.text: In a 45-year-old male patient from Bihar with a normo-anesthetic hypopigmented lesion and a history of prolonged fever in childhood, what is the probable clinical diagnosis, considering the absence of thickened nerves?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Post-kala-azar dermal leishmaniasis (PKDL)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Post-kala-azar dermal leishmaniasis (PKDL) occurs in patients who have recovered from visceral leishmaniasis . It presents with hypopigmented macules and nodular lesions, especially in endemic regions such as Bihar. Diagnosis is confirmed by detecting amastigotes (Leishman-Donovan bodies) on Giemsa-stained slit skin smears.
  • ➤ Post-kala-azar dermal leishmaniasis (PKDL)
  • ➤ visceral leishmaniasis
  • ➤ amastigotes (Leishman-Donovan bodies)
  • ➤ Giemsa-stained

questions.text: Match the woods lamp findings with their respective diseases:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 1-e),2-c),3-d),4-b)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Wood's lamp uses UVA light with a wavelength of 365nm ( 320 - 400 nm) for the diagnosis of various skin conditions based on the fluorescence characteristics of the skin under this specific range of ultraviolet light.
  • ➤ Wood's
  • ➤ UVA
  • ➤ 365nm
  • ➤ 320
  • ➤ 400
  • ➤ fluorescence

questions.text: A 42-year-old truck driver presents with a painless, indurated genital ulcer after engaging in unprotected sexual intercourse. The motility of the causative agent can be detected by which type of microscope?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Dark field microscope

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The motility of Treponema pallidum, the causative agent of syphilis, can be detected using a dark field microscope.

questions.text: Which component of the skin cells is most directly responsible for the critical barrier function?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Lamellar bodies

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Lamellar bodies in the epidermis are essential for the skin's barrier function as they release lipids that prevent water loss and protect against external pathogens. Understanding the role of these structures is important for comprehending the pathophysiology of skin barrier disorders.

questions.text: A 35-year-old Lady developed painless beefy red genital ulcer with swelling in inguinal area. On biopsy, safety pin appearance was noted. Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Granuloma inguinale

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Determine that Granuloma inguinale is the likely diagnosis for a patient presenting with painless beefy red genital ulcers , supported by characteristic
  • ➤ Granuloma inguinale
  • ➤ painless beefy red genital ulcers

questions.text: A 8-year-old child presents with patchy hair loss, itching, and scaling of the scalp, as shown in the image below. The affected areas show broken hairs and scaling. What is the next best step in diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) KOH mount

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For children with patchy hair loss , scaling , and broken hairs on the scalp, the next best step is a KOH mount to confirm tinea capitis , a fungal infection. The KOH mount is an easy and effective method to visualize fungal elements.
  • ➤ patchy hair loss
  • ➤ scaling
  • ➤ broken hairs
  • ➤ KOH mount
  • ➤ tinea capitis

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents to the dermatology clinic with concerns about significant hair shedding that began several months after she experienced a high fever and was diagnosed with COVID-19. Which condition is most consistent with this presentation?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Telogen effluvium

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Stressors such as severe infection, patients may present with telogen effluvium, a condition characterized by diffuse hair shedding that is usually self-limited and resolves over time as new hair growth occurs.

questions.text: Identify the cause(s) that result in non-scarring alopecia from the following: Alopecia areata Telogen effluvium Androgenic alopecia Frontal fibrosing alopecia
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 1, 2, and 3

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Alopecia areata, telogen effluvium, and androgenic alopecia as conditions that can cause non-scarring alopecia where hair loss does not result in permanent scarring and may be reversible.

questions.text: Identify this type of baldness:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Male pattern baldness

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In evaluating hair loss, recognize the pattern and distribution of baldness. Male pattern baldness is characterized by a receding hairline and thinning on the crown, consistent with the image provided, and differs from the patterns seen in alopecia areata, telogen effluvium, and cicatricial hair loss.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female came with chief complaints of vaginal discharge with lower abdominal pain and cervical motion tenderness. which color kit will you prescribe her?
questions.explanation: Ans. C) Yellow (6)

questions.text: Identify this micro-organism (spiral-shaped spirochete) which is shown in the image.
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) All of the above

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ All three organisms, Treponema pallidum, Borrelia recurrentis, and Leptospira interrogans, are spirochetes, characterized by their spiral shape.

questions.text: Based on the patient's history of relapsing, remitting, mildly itchy erythematous plaques on the scalp, sacral area, and knees, along with joint pain and the displayed nail changes in the image below, what would be your diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Psoriasis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Nail changes in psoriasis can include nail pitting , onycholysis , and the "oil drop" sign . Psoriasis can involve the skin, nails, and joints, making it essential to consider these features in the diagnosis of patients presenting with joint pain and typical skin lesions.
  • ➤ psoriasis
  • ➤ nail pitting
  • ➤ onycholysis
  • ➤ "oil drop" sign

questions.text: A patient presents to you with multiple anogenital warts. The biopsy of these lesions showed squamous atypia. Which of the following HPV types are considered high risk?
questions.explanation: Ans. B) HPV 18

questions.text: The following lines are not a pattern of apparent leukonychia?
questions.explanation: Ans. B) Beau's lines

questions.text: Match the Diseases in Colum A with STI Kit colour in Colum B:
questions.explanation: Ans. A) 1-b, 2-c, 3-a

questions.text: During clinical postings, a medical student notices that a patient with circular areas of patchy hair loss on their scalp also has irregularities on their nails. The student is asked to identify the nail finding most commonly associated with this type of hair loss. Which nail finding would be expected in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Nail pitting

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Nail pitting is a common finding in patients with alopecia areata, reflecting the systemic nature of autoimmune conditions that can affect both the skin and its appendages.

questions.text: The below image depicts warty growths around anogenital region. Try to Identify the condition shown?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Condyloma acuminata

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Identify condyloma acuminata by their characteristic cauliflower-like appearance in the genital and anal regions, differentiating them from other conditions like Bowen disease and condyloma lata.

questions.text: A 24-year-old man presents to the dermatology clinic with severe, painful nodules and cysts on his face and upper back. He reports that over-the-counter treatments have been ineffective. The dermatologist diagnoses him with nodulocystic acne and recommends the most appropriate treatment to address his condition. Which of the following is the treatment of choice for the above discussed clinical condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 13-cis Retinoic Acid

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ 13-cis Retinoic Acid (isotretinoin) is the treatment of choice for nodulocystic acne due to its effectiveness in reducing sebaceous gland activity and promoting long-term remission.

questions.text: Identify the incorrect statement among the following:

options.label: B
options.text: Chancroid & Herpes present as painful genital ulcers

options.label: C
options.text: School of fish appearance is seen in Hemophilus ducreyi

questions.correct_answer: D. Gonorrhea presents with genital ulcer
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Gonorrhea presents with genital ulcer

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The educational objective is to recognize the typical presentations of sexually transmitted infections. Understanding that gonorrhea typically presents with a discharge rather than an ulcer is important for differential diagnosis and appropriate management of sexually transmitted infections.

questions.text: A 42-year-old male construction worker presents with itchy, red, and weeping plaques on his palms and forearms, as depicted in the image. He reports that the rash developed shortly after he started working with wet cement on a new project. He denies any known allergies or atopic history. On examination, the skin lesions are erythematous, with vesicles and some crusting, localized to areas of contact with cement. What is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?

options.label: B
options.text: Perform Patch Test to confirm the Diagnosis

questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Start with Steroids

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Treatment with topical steroids should be initiated to reduce inflammation and provide symptomatic relief . Medical students should be aware that while patch testing is useful for diagnosis, the immediate treatment of the dermatitis should NOT be delayed for testing.
  • ➤ Treatment with topical steroids should be initiated to reduce inflammation and provide symptomatic relief .
  • ➤ topical steroids
  • ➤ reduce inflammation
  • ➤ symptomatic relief
  • ➤ Medical students should be aware that while patch testing is useful for diagnosis, the immediate treatment of the dermatitis should NOT be delayed for testing.
  • ➤ Medical students
  • ➤ patch testing
  • ➤ NOT be delayed

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy presents with multiple hyperpigmented macules on his trunk. Notably, when one of the lesions is stroked with the rounded end of a pen, an urticarial wheal appears that is restricted to the margins of the macule. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Urticaria pigmentosa

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hyperpigmented macules that develop urticarial wheals when stroked, a finding known as Darier's sign,is indicative of cutaneous mastocytosis.
  • ➤ Hyperpigmented macules that develop urticarial wheals when stroked, a finding known as Darier's sign,is indicative of cutaneous mastocytosis.

questions.text: Assertion: Patients with atopic eczema have more staphylococcal infections Reason: Patients with atopic eczema have barrier dysfunction

options.label: A
options.text: Both Assertion and Reason are true, and Reason is correct explanation of Assertion

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: Assertion is true and Reason is false

options.label: D
options.text: Assertion is false and Reason is true. Both Assertion and Reason are false

questions.correct_answer: A. Both Assertion and Reason are true, and Reason is correct explanation of Assertion
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Both Assertion and Reason are true, and Reason is correct explanation of Assertion

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Patients with atopic eczema have an increased risk of staphylococcal infections due to the compromised barrier function of their skin.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman presents with a two-year history of erythematous papules and pustules on her face, particularly on her cheeks and nose, as shown in the image. The lesions are associated with a background of persistent erythema and telangiectasia. She denies any involvement around her mouth or eyes. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Rosacea

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Rosacea presents as erythematous papules and pustules on the convexities of the face, with a background of persistent erythema and telangiectasia. It commonly affects middle-aged individuals and lacks comedones, differentiating it from acne vulgaris.
  • ➤ Rosacea

questions.text: A 22-year-old college student presents with small depigmented lesions which have been there for over 2 years now as shown in the image below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Vitiligo

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Diagnose Vitiligo based on the presence of well-demarcated depigmented patches , differentiating it from other skin conditions like Melasma, Psoriasis, and Dermatitis herpetiformis which present with hyperpigmentation, scaly plaques, and vesicles, respectively.
  • ➤ Vitiligo
  • ➤ well-demarcated depigmented patches
  • ➤ Melasma, Psoriasis, and Dermatitis herpetiformis
  • ➤ hyperpigmentation, scaly plaques, and vesicles,

questions.text: A 24-year-old female presents with the following lesions in axilla. What's your diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Hidradenitis suppurativa

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ When encountering a patient with chronic lesions in the axilla presenting as multiple sinuses and scars, consider Hidradenitis suppurativa as the most likely diagnosis. This condition is characterized by nodules, abscesses, sinus tract formation, and scarring, commonly affecting areas with apocrine sweat glands.

questions.text: Which of the following chemical is responsible for this clinical picture?

options.label: D
options.text: Crocein Scarlet MOO and Solvent Yellow 3

questions.explanation: Ans. B) Para Tertiary butylphenol (PTBP)

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents to the dermatology clinic with well-demarcated, red, scaly plaques on her elbows and knees. She has a known history of psoriasis. The physician reviews common and uncommon characteristics of psoriasis to provide patient education. Which of the following statements about this condition is not true?

options.label: A
options.text: Head, neck, and face are not involved

options.label: B
options.text: Arthritis is seen in 5% of cases

options.label: C
options.text: Neutrophilic microabscesses are seen in lesions

options.label: D
options.text: Non-scaly, red lesions are seen in inframammary and natal regions.

questions.correct_answer: A. Head, neck, and face are not involved
questions.explanation: Ans. A) Head, neck, and face are not involved

questions.text: Identify the following condition as shown in the images?.
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Piebaldism

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Diagnose piebaldism by recognizing its hallmark presentation with a white forelock and patchy leukoderma present at birth, distinguishing it from other pigmentary disorders such as vitiligo, xeroderma pigmentosum, and incontinentia pigmenti.

questions.text: In which of the following disorders is the following sign seen?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Dermatomyositis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Dermatomyositis is characterized by a distinctive violaceous rash and muscle weakness, differentiating it from other autoimmune diseases such as systemic lupus erythematosus, discoid lupus erythematosus, and scleroderma.

questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 1-c, 2-b, 3-a, 4-d

  • ➤ Acitretin is teratogenic and can cause mucositis (4-d).

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents to the clinic with a two-day history of rapidly evolving rash after experiencing vesicles over his lips. He reports a burning sensation followed by the appearance of concentric erythematous rings on his palms. He denies any recent illness, medication changes, or new exposures. He has a past medical history significant for recurrent herpes labialis. On examination, you note several round lesions with central erythema, intermediate zone of pallor and peripheral erythema, as depicted in the image. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Erythema multiforme

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Erythema multiforme has target lesions, often precipitated by a herpes simplex infection in a patient.

questions.text: A 47-year-old woman presents to the clinic with complaints of persistent, painful lesions in her mouth. On examination, you notice white, lace-like patches on the buccal mucosa. She also mentions occasional itchy, purplish, flat-topped bumps on her wrists. What is the most likely diagnosis of this clinical scenario?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Lichen Planus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Lichen planus is associated with characteristic oral lesions, presenting as white, lace-like patches on the mucous membranes.

questions.text: A 11-year-old boy is being evaluated for seizures and developmental delay. During the examination, the physician notes multiple skin lesions suggestive of adenoma sebaceum and performs a detailed review of systems and imaging studies to identify associated conditions. Which of the following is NOT typically seen in the boy with the most likely diagnosis possible with the above clinical findings?
questions.explanation: Ans. A) Iris Nodule

questions.text: A 23-year-old female presents to the clinic with a widespread, itchy rash that started a week after she noticed a single, large, scaly, erythematous patch on her back. She states that the larger patch was followed by multiple smaller, oval lesions that spread centripetally and aligned along the lines of skin tension, also known as the 'Christmas tree pattern.' She denies any recent infections or medication changes and reports that she is otherwise healthy. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Pityriasis rosea

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pityriasis rosea has herald patch followed by a 'Christmas tree' distribution of secondary annular lesions with peripheral scaling along the lines of skin tension.

questions.text: A 23-year-old Patient presents with history of severe sunburn after only a few minutes in the sun (photo sensitivity), freckling in sun exposed areas, dry skin and changes in skin pigmentation. What is your Diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Diagnose Xeroderma pigmentosum based on the clinical presentation of severe photosensitivity, freckling in sun-exposed areas, dry skin, and changes in pigmentation, along with an increased risk for skin cancers.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman presents to the dermatology clinic with a rash. Upon examination, you notice that the rash has a distinctive pattern and distribution. Considering her age and the appearance of the skin condition, you are evaluating her for possible underlying internal malignancy. Which of the following skin conditions is LEAST likely to be associated with underlying internal malignancy?
questions.explanation: Ans. C) Granuloma annulare

questions.text: A 43-year-old female with no significant past medical history presents to the clinic with complaints of chronic, scaly plaques that have been persisting for several months. She mentions that the rash tends to worsen with stress and cold weather. On examination, you notice well-demarcated, thick, erythematous plaques covered with silvery-white scales on the extensor aspects of her elbows and knees. Removal of the scale leads to pinpoint bleeding. Which of the following clinical signs is likely to be positive in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Auspitz sign

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Psoriasis presents as well-demarcated, erythematous plaques with silvery-white scales and the positive Auspitz sign, which is pinpoint bleeding following scale removal.

questions.text: A 34-year-old patient presents with flat-topped violaceous papules and thinning of nails. What microscopic finding is observed in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Max Joseph Space

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Recognize the histological finding of Max Joseph spaces in lichen planus, which correlates with the clinical presentation of flat-topped, violaceous papules.

questions.text: A patient came with complaints of diarrhea, dermatitis and mental retardation. It was also found that he was a maize eater. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Ans. C) Pellagra

questions.text: A 62-year-old male presents with multiple tense, itchy bullae on an erythematous, urticarial base. The patient reports severe itching. After some time, the roof of the bullae got settled. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Bullous pemphigoid

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Bullous pemphigoid is characterized by tense bullae on an erythematous base, often associated with intense pruritus, typically affecting elderly patients. It is caused by autoantibodies against hemidesmosomes in the basement membrane, leading to subepidermal blistering.
  • ➤ Bullous pemphigoid
  • ➤ tense bullae

questions.text: A 6-year-old girl presents with rough, keratotic papules on her elbows and knees, which have become more prominent over the past few months. Her mother reports that the child has been having difficulty seeing in low-light conditions. Physical examination reveals bumpy skin on the extensor surfaces and a bitot's spot on the conjunctiva. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Phrynoderma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Phrynoderma is a skin condition associated with vitamin A deficiency, presenting with rough, keratotic papules on the extensor surfaces and can be associated with night blindness due to the systemic effects of the vitamin deficiency.

questions.text: A 42-year-old female presents with blistering skin lesions. The blisters are fragile and rupture easily, leaving a denuded surface. A biopsy reveals intraepidermal splitting. Which of the following conditions is characterized by bullous skin lesions with intraepidermal split?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) All of the above

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Intraepidermal blistering can occur in several conditions, including pemphigus vulgaris, Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome (SSSS), and epidermolysis bullosa simplex. Each of these conditions leads to bullous lesions due to different underlying mechanisms but shares the common feature of intraepidermal splitting.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman with a BMI greater than 30 presents to the dermatology clinic with velvety, hyperpigmented lesions on her skin. Which condition is most commonly associated with these findings?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Metabolic syndrome

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Velvety hyperpigmented lesions, particularly in a patient with a high BMI, are suggestive of Acanthosis nigricans, which is associated with insulin resistance and metabolic syndrome.

questions.text: A 34-year-old male presents with intensely pruritic papulovesicular lesions localized on his knees, elbows, upper back, and buttocks. Direct immunofluorescence (DIF) of the lesions shows granular deposits of IgA at the basement membrane zone (BMZ) and dermal papillae. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Dermatitis herpetiformis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Identify dermatitis herpetiformis by its clinical presentation of pruritic papulovesicular lesions and the granular deposition of IgA at the basement membrane zone and dermal papillae on direct immunofluorescence.

questions.text: Which of the following deficiency can lead to the following clinical picture?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Zinc

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Recognize acrodermatitis enteropathica as a disorder resulting from zinc deficiency, characterized by dermatitis, alopecia, and diarrhea, which responds well to zinc supplementation.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presents to the dermatology clinic with a slowly enlarging lesion on his face that has been present for several months. On examination, the lesion is a pearly, translucent nodule with surface telangiectasia. The patient is concerned about the nature of the lesion. Which of the following statements is INCORRECT regarding this condition?
questions.correct_answer: C. There is a pre-malignant stage
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) There is a pre-malignant stage

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Basal cell carcinoma typically does not have a premalignant stage and is characterized by slow growth and extremely rare metastasis.

questions.text: Among the blistering diseases listed below, which would not demonstrate a positive direct Immunofluorescence (DIF) test? Dermatitis herpetiformis Hailey-Hailey Disease Pemphigus foliaceus Epidermolysis bullosa simplex Bullous pemphigoid
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 2 and 4 only

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Understand that Hailey-Hailey Disease and Epidermolysis bullosa simplex are genetic disorders that would not show a positive direct Immunofluorescence test, unlike autoimmune blistering diseases like dermatitis herpetiformis, pemphigus foliaceus, and bullous pemphigoid.

questions.text: Identify the condition shown in the image?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Malignant melanoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Identify malignant melanoma by the ABCDE criteria of Asymmetry, Border irregularity, Color variation, Diameter over 6 mm, and Evolving characteristics, distinguishing it from other skin cancers like BCC and SCC which present with different clinical features.

questions.text: Cutaneous horn is shown in the image below. It is most likely associated with which of the following skin cancer?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Squamous cell carcinoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Recognize that cutaneous horns are often associated with underlying squamous cell carcinoma and that any such lesion should be biopsied to determine the nature of the base tissue.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man undergoing Anti PD1 immunotherapy (Nivolumab) presents with itching, eczema, and hives-like rashes. Upon histopathological analysis, a blister beneath the outer skin layer is observed. The direct immunofluorescence assessment of the affected areas indicates the presence of Linear C3 and IgG along the basement membrane. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Bullous pemphigoid

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Recognize drug-induced bullous pemphigoid as a potential side effect of Anti PD-1 immunotherapy, diagnosed by subepidermal blistering and linear C3 and IgG deposits along the basement membrane on direct immunofluorescence.

questions.text: A 38-year-old man presents to the clinic with complaints of persistently dry skin and the presence of a "fish scale" pattern over his lower extremities as shown in the image. He reports that the condition has been present since childhood and tends to worsen in the winter months. His past medical history is unremarkable, and he takes no medications. Physical examination reveals large, polygonal scales that are darkly pigmented and adhere firmly to the underlying skin. Which epidermal layer is the protein that is deficient in this patient's condition primarily located?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Stratum granulosum

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In ichthyosis vulgaris, there is a deficiency in profilaggrin, which is synthesized in the stratum granulosum and is crucial for the formation of filaggrin, a protein that contributes to the hydration and barrier function of the skin.

questions.text: A 46-year-old man presents with painful, flaccid bullae on his skin and erosions in his mouth. Some of the bullae have ruptured, leaving behind raw, erosions over the skin. A Tzanck smear from one of the lesions shows acantholytic cells. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Pemphigus vulgaris

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pemphigus vulgaris is an autoimmune blistering disorder characterized by flaccid bullae , mucosal involvement, and the presence of acantholytic cells on Tzanck smear. It is caused by autoantibodies against desmogleins, leading to the loss of keratinocyte adhesion.
  • ➤ Pemphigus vulgaris
  • ➤ flaccid bullae
  • ➤ acantholytic cells

questions.text: Which of the following types of leprosy is most likely associated with a negative skin smear report?
questions.explanation: Ans. B) Neuritic type leprosy

questions.text: Which of the following drugs used in leprosy treatment causes cutaneous Hyperpigmentation?
questions.explanation: Ans. C) Clofazimine

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to the clinic with a variety of skin lesions. Considering his clinical history and symptoms, the physician suspects leprosy. The physician reviews the common types of skin lesions associated with leprosy to confirm the diagnosis. Which of the following lesions is LEAST likely to be seen in leprosy?
questions.explanation: Ans. B) Vesicles

questions.text: Which upper limb nerve is commonly biopsied to diagnose neuritic leprosy?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Radial cutaneous nerve

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The radial cutaneous nerve of the upper limb is often biopsied in cases of pure neuritic leprosy because it is a sensory nerve, minimizing the risk of motor dysfunction while providing adequate tissue for diagnostic purposes.
  • ➤ radial cutaneous nerve of the upper limb
  • ➤ pure neuritic leprosy

questions.text: A 32-year-old man presents with an annular lesion on his back, as shown in the image. The lesion has an inverted saucer shape with a perpendicular inner margin. The patient reports that the lesion is numb to touch. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Borderline leprosy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Borderline leprosy presents with well-defined, asymmetrical lesions that often have an inverted saucer shape and sensory loss. The involvement of peripheral nerves by Mycobacterium leprae leads to the sensory deficits commonly associated with this form of leprosy.
  • ➤ Borderline leprosy
  • ➤ inverted saucer shape

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presents with chronic, extensive red, scaly plaques on his skin, consistent with psoriasis vulgaris as shown in the image. The patient has a history of poor response to topical treatments and is now considering systemic therapy. Which of the following is NOT commonly used as a systemic therapy for his condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Prednisolone

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Systemic corticosteroids, such as prednisolone, are generally not recommended for long-term treatment of psoriasis because of the risk of rebound flares upon discontinuation and complications of pustular and erythrodermic psoriasis.

questions.text: Identify the incorrect statement regarding the condition shown in the image?

options.label: A
options.text: Pressure bearing or friction areas are most commonly affected

questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Usually associated with anhidrosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pitted keratolysis is a bacterial infection affecting pressure-bearing areas of the feet, often associated with foul odor and hyperhidrosis. It is caused by Corynebacterium species and is not associated with anhidrosis.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man consults regarding a asymptomatic rash he has noticed around his groin since 5 months. On examination there is a symmetrical well-demarcated, brown-red macular rash around the groin. Wood lamp examination is shown in the image Most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Erythrasma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ When presented with a well-demarcated, brown-red macular rash in the groin that fluoresces coral red under Wood's lamp, Erythrasma should be considered the most likely diagnosis.

questions.text: A 7-year-old child presents with the condition as shown after a pharyngeal infection. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Identify Staphylococcal Scalded Skin Syndrome by its clinical presentation of widespread blistering and desquamation that resembles scalded skin, often following a staphylococcal pharyngeal infection in infants and young children.

questions.text: A 36-year-old female presents with painful, erythematous nodules on the anterior aspects of her legs. The lesions appeared symmetrically over the course of a few days and are tender to touch. She reports no recent illness or new medications. Which of the following statements about this condition is false?

options.label: B
options.text: They are considered to be a hypersensitivity reaction

options.label: C
options.text: It is a type of lobular panniculitis

questions.correct_answer: C. It is a type of lobular panniculitis
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) It is a type of lobular panniculitis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Erythema nodosum is a cutaneous reactive septal panniculitis that presents with symmetrical, tender subcutaneous nodules, and is considered a type IV hypersensitivity reaction. It is not a type of lobular panniculitis.

questions.text: A 25-year-old pregnant woman, with no history of chickenpox or vaccination for the same, is currently living with her brother who has recently developed varicella. She underwent testing for varicella zoster virus (VZV) antibodies, which returned negative. What does her serological status imply regarding her susceptibility to VZV?
questions.correct_answer: B. She is susceptible to chickenpox.
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) She is susceptible to chickenpox.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A negative varicella zoster virus antibody test in an individual with no history of chickenpox or vaccination indicates susceptibility to chickenpox, which can be particularly concerning in a pregnant woman due to the risks to both the mother and the fetus.

questions.text: A 40-year-old immunocompromised patient presents with the following lesion on the lateral aspect of the tongue as shown in the image below. This white membrane was not scrapeable with a gauze piece. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Oral Hairy Leucoplakia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Diagnose Oral Hairy Leukoplakia by its characteristic non-scrapeable, white, hairy appearance on the lateral aspect of the tongue, especially in i mmunocompromised patients.
  • ➤ Diagnose Oral Hairy Leukoplakia by its characteristic non-scrapeable, white, hairy appearance on the lateral aspect of the tongue, especially in i mmunocompromised patients.
  • ➤ Oral Hairy Leukoplakia
  • ➤ non-scrapeable, white, hairy appearance on the lateral
  • ➤ mmunocompromised

questions.text: A 35-year-old male with a history of HIV presents with white plaques on his lateral tongue that cannot be scraped off. Based on this presentation, which virus is most commonly associated with this finding?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) EBV (Epstein-Barr Virus)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Oral hairy leukoplakia is an EBV-associated lesion typically seen in immunocompromised patients, presenting as white plaques on the lateral tongue that cannot be scraped off.

questions.text: A 6-year-old Child presents with sores in the mouth and a rash on the hands and feet as shown in the image below. What is the causative organism for it?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Coxsackievirus A16

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Identify Coxsackievirus A16 as the causative agent of hand, foot, and mouth disease, characterized by sores in the mouth and a vesicular rash on the hands and feet in children.
